ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Grew in my speaking and writing skills in Italian and also reiterated a lot of the grammar topics from L1 and L2.
Continuation of L1 and L2 Italian. Deeper dive into concepts covered in the previous two semesters with a focus on improving speaking skills.
General knowledge of the Italian Language at the intermediate grade.
This course reviews a lot of the topics from L1 & L2 with a little more depth.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There are no weaknesses except maybe that there are daily quizzes with Michael but they force you to study every day which is very helpful when learning a language. Strengths: everything else.

I really preferred Prof Farinas teaching. Daily quizzes forced me to learn more than doing homework, and I found I spent less time studying than I would have spent doing homework and learned more from knowing Id be quizzed on it.

Strengths: If you are going to take an Italian class, take one with Professor Farina. He teaches you so much of the language that at the end of the semester you asses your own learning and realized that you have such a strong grasp of the language.
Strengths: MICHAEL FARINA!!! Exams were very manageable, as well as the coursework

I think that both the strength and weakness of this course are found in the professor. Micheal is really lovely, and he wants you to succeed, but make no mistake that this class requires effort. It's not a gut. You have to go to class, and you have to sort of play the game that Micheal creates. If you play the game, and do the assignments, Micheal will ensure that you do well, but if you don't... you're in hot water.
The fact that this class meets every day is a strength in the sense that it really forces you to interact with the language.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you are already in the Italian track please take L3 with Michael!!! It is very relaxed but also helps you to learn and apply Italian very frequently.

YES! Italian is the perfect language to learn at Yale for the language requirement --- great department (Michael Farina is absolutely the highlight, a fantastic professor) and great faculty in general, Italian as a language isn't very hard to learn especially if you've already learned Spanish or French, L3 is basically a review of everything you learned in L1 and L2 so, personally, it was the easiest of all the levels
I would, particularly if they want to learn Italian from someone who loves teaching it.
Yes, would definitely recommend it if Michael is teaching!
Yes, great language credit especially if taught by Michael
